Remains of two lines of Latin letters across the stone, with traces of a third line in Greek below

Thinly incised letters with terminal points/serifs to the strokes. Greek letters are much smaller than Latin letters. The M tends lightly towards the cursive form, and some letters join at the foot; A in the Latin text has an upward sloping cross-bar; Greek text appears to have lunate epsilon.
1st century or beginning of 2nd century CE (Korhonen)

Bilingual sign advertising engraving of inscriptions

The text fills the face of the plaque, divided vertically by a deeply incised line into two unequal halves, with a column of Greek on the left (wider) and Latin on the right). Each column is approximately centred, and consists of seven lines of text, with the first two lines notably larger than the following five.
Greek text includes lunate sigma and epsilon; extended apex to delta and alpha. Latin text is is regular with serifs, open P, closed R. There are no word dividers or punctuation in either text.

Augustan or Julio-Claudian,
                                by the letter forms; also, archaic spelling of some of the Latin, with other Sicilian
                                parallels, rules out much later date (so Wilson 1990); Manni Piraino thinks later 2nd century CE

Eight lines of Greek letters, with the first two lines slightly indented compared to the rest, and a vacat below.

Deeply incised letters, slightly elongated. Alpha is extended at the top, with straight bar; epsilon is in form of a four-bar sigma with middle bar extended to match top and bottom strokes; zeta is regular Z; theta rhomboid with full middle bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has all strokes off vertical, with the middle strokes not fully descending; omicron is rhomboid; pi has overextended crossbar; rho has rounded and closed head; sigma is regular four-bar; omega is rhomboid but open at the base.

Monumental letters without serifs, but with a widening towards the end of terminal strokes. Straight bar alpha; beta with equal loops, closed; epsilon with shorter middle bar; Mu with verical first and last, shorter mid-strokes; omicron consistently smaller and mid-line; rho with closed loop; sigma with slightly open top and bottom strokes, mid-strokes only part width; phi with a small elliptical eye.
In the period subsequent to the establishment of the co-regency of Hieron II and Gelon (i.e. after 241/240 BCE)

The Technitai of Dionysos honour Skymnos

Neat and regular letters of the later Hellenistic period, in some cases with pronounced serifs. Omicron is full-size; omega is closed; epsilon has shorter middle bar; mu has splayed outer hastae; kappa on occasion has short arms; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; pi has equal vertical strokes and the horizontal overhangs on both sides.

The text appears to observes the shape of the stone, with a fixed left margin and the lines fitting to the line of breakage on the right, and a staurogram centrally filling the space below. The letters retain traces of red paint throughout.

Slightly irregular but neatly carved plain letters without serifs. Alpha has straight bar; Epsilon is rectilinear, with mostly equal length bars; Theta is large and voice, with a full width horizontal bar; Kappa generally has short arms; Lamda has a slight extension at the top; Mu (in ligature) has vertical virst and last, with diagonals extending only half-way down;' rho has small head, closed; sigma is lunate but rectilinear; omega is lunate. Interpuncts are used around numerals.
Photo Museo Arch. Reg. P. Orsi (2012), Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

The text maintains a regular left margin, ignoring the irregularity of the form of the stone, and filling the space to the right; however, the cutter ran out of space at the end of the stone, and inserted the remaining letters of the word Δεκεμβρίῳ and the concluding staurogram, firstly at the end of line 2 (letter β) and then, under a 'paragraphos' line to the left of the main text of line 2, level with lines 3 (letters ριω) and 4 (staurogram)

plainly cut, relatively regular letters, in a curved groove rather than v-cut, without serifs. Alpha has an oblique crossbar, sloping down to left, and a horizontal stroke to left off the top of the letter; beta has closed eyes, the upper is smaller; epsilon is lunate (except for the first in line 5 which is rectilinear); zeta has regular Z form; kappa has near full-legnth arms; mu has cursive form; omicron is full size; rho has closed eye; sigma is lunate; omega is lunate.
Photo Museo Arch. Reg. P. Orsi (2015), Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

l.4 Ὀ

Seven lines of Greek letters, with traces of red paint. Lines 1-3 are more formally / monumentally carved, from line four onwards the carving is lighter and less carefully laid out, rising to the right.

Simple, thinly incised letters without serfis or terminations. The letters become increasingly ireregular and variable in the final lines. Alpha has striaght bar but also broken and oblique bar; beta has closed roughly equal eyes; Epsilon is quadrate with equal length bars; Zeta is Z in form but irregular; theta is ovoid with full straight bar; kappa has shorter arms; omicron mostly slightly smaller than other letters; sigma is lunate but square in form, lower bar slanting downwards, except for the irregular curved instance end of line 2; omega is in the form of a w, but formed entirely of straight lines and right angles. interlineation is highly irregular throughout.
Photo J. Prag (2018), Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

Six lines of text, of which the first four are neatly and regularly set out between guidelines, but the final two are squeezed into the remaining space, centred but unevenly and without guidelines.

Clear V-cut letters without serifs of somewhat uneven width, consistent height over the first four lines, more irregular thereafter. Alpha with broken bar and stroke rising off the apex; Beta with closed but separated eyes; delta with stroke rising off the apex; epsilon lunate in line 1 but regular in line 2; theta ovoid with full straight cross-bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has vertical first and last, and short middle strokes; omicron varies in size and from round to ovoid; pi is equal length with overlapping horizontal; rho has small closed eye; sigma is lunate, but rectilinear; omega is lunate and small above the line.

Line 1 is inscribed across the upper moulding (which is heavily damaged); the remainder of the text is engraved on the recessed front face, in two columns. The spacing between the columns after the first line is very irregular; column 2 has a half-line gap after line 2, meaning that the lines in the two columns are vertically out of synch after this point.

Neatly carved and regular letters, mostly without serifs, but some terminal wedges. Alpha with straight bar; epsilon on occasion has a slightly shorter mid-bar; zeta in form of I with wide horizontals; theta has short detached cross-bar; kappa has full-length arms; mu has vertical first and last, full length mid-strokes; xsi has three equal horiztonal bars; omicron is only slightly smaller than the other letters; pi has extended horizontal; rho has small rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom, with slihgtly variable mid-strokes; phi has small oval eye, with vertical often extended; omega is notably variable, always closed, but ranging from tear-drop to full circle on or even above and detached from the base line.
11-15 (with omicron down to 9 and phi up to 20)
Later third or second century BCE on palaeographic grounds.

The text is laid out in a single column, with a consistent left margin, with every second line indented by c.1 letter; the right margin is irregular.

Letters are plainly cut with minimal serifs and a square module. Alpha has straight bar; beta has equal closed loops; epsilon sometimes has equal length strokes, sometimes shorter middle bar; theta is full size, slightly elliptical, with plain cross-bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes only half-descending; pi has overlapping horizontal, equal length vertical strokes; rho has closed eye of moderate size; sigma has horizontal upper and lower strokes; phi has an ovoid eye of varying size and extended vertical; omega varies between teardrop, rhomboid and small circle, always closed with horizontal baseline.

Very regular neat v-cut letters. The text is centred on the stone. Note the use of horizontal lines/dashes between the name and patronym of the officials. Sigma is four bar and open; Pi has short second vertical; omicron and omega are small, the latter closed.
Probably Hieronian in date, given the letter forms and the content.

Decree in honour of a gymnasiarch
The text, occupying 47 lines, fills the upper two-thirds of the main rectangular portion of the stele.

The lettering is tight, both in between letters and in interlinear spaces. The first two lines are larger and more spaced, though not necessarily more precise in execution. Alpha appears with both a straight and a curved crossbar. Interchangeable use of four-bar and lunate sigma, often in the same line, often close together. Interchangeable use of square and lunate epsilon, same variability and position as with sigma. There is occasional omission of the middle bar of a lunate epsilon, particularly in between two sigmas, resulting visually in the combination CCC. This occurs both at the beginning and end of lines, and does not seem to correspond to textual cues. Omega is mostly rhomboid or ovoid, occasionally round, though the few round instances seem to be an execution issue with the ovoid variant rather than a stylistic choice.
(Later) second or first century BCE (Dubois and Cordiano suggest 1st cent. BCE)

Four lines of Greek letters, all crudely incised in the epigraphic field on the front face.

The first two lines are deeply incised, the second two very lightly incised. Alpha has straight bar, with an apex; epsilon has equal length horizontals; mu in line 3 has extended apices, in anticipation of the cursive form; omicron is circular in lines 1 and 3, angular (made up of straight lines) in lines 3 and 4; sigma is and open four bar sigma in lines 1-2, a quadrate lunate sigma in lines 3-4; phi has a small elongated eye; omega is open in lines 1-2, lunate in line 4. It is therefore likely that lines 1-2 were incised by a different hand from lines 3-4.
Potentially lines 1-2 (Hellenistic) predate lines 3-4 (late Hellenistic or Roman) by a century or two.

Four lines of Greek letters centred on the face of the stone, but with a leftward bias.

Very neatly carved wide, regular letters of a fairly square module, with minimal serifs and all letters of near equal size. Straight bar alpha; epsilon with only slightly shorter middle bar; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes descen half-way; omicron near full size; pi has equal length verticals with slight overhang on both sides of the cross bar; rho has large rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is circular and without over-extended vertical; omega is open and tear-drop shaped.
late second century BCE, or early C1 BCE, following Ampolo and Erdas (previously dated earlier by Nenci) and confirmed by parallel material

Seven lines of Greek letters, filling the face, with a regular left margin, the final line approximately centred; the text is engraved by means of individual dots punched with a rounded tool.

Regular neatly cut letters, with pronounced terminations to the strokes. Alpha has broken bar; beta a much smaller upper eye, just closed; epsilon has nearly equal strokes; zeta formed by vertical with horizontal top and bottom; kappa has shortened arms; mu has midstrokes descending only half-way, curved rather than angular, and not always reaching the top of the verticals; xsi formed by three horizontals only, the middle one shorter; omicron is full size; pi has horizontal extending beyond the verticals; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is standard height, with ovoid eye; omega is closed, and tear-drop shaped.
Later second or earlier first century BCE

The text is approximately centred, but with a notable bias to the left; only the final line fills the entire width of the face. The spacing between lines is somewhat irregular.

Plainly cut letters without serifs, of slightly irregular width and height. Alpha has a straight bar, sometimes with curvature; epsilon has shorter middle bar; theta has a detached middle bar; kappa with near full length arms; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes not fully descending and curving at apex; omicron slihgtly smaller and above the line; pi has equal length verticals and overlapping horizontal; sigma has parallel outer strokes, half-width mid-strokes with curving apex; upsilon has straight arms;l phi has oval eye and extended vertical; omega is circular, open at the base, with horizontal feet.
mid-third to mid-second century BCE on the basis of the lettering.

The text appears to be laid out with a more or less consistent left margin, vacats to the right.

Regularly cut letters with terminal serifs including horizontal caps to the tops of the alphas. Alpha has generally curved crossbar, sometimes equivalent to broken bar; epsilon has detached middle bar in the form of a triangle; theta has central point; kappa has full-length arms; omicron is full-size; pi has equal length verticals and overlapping horizontal; rho has a tapering eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom, which overextend to left, the mid-strokes extending halfway, and straight; upsilon has straight arms; omega is tear-drop shaped, and closed, on a horizontal line.

Funerary inscription for a family, including Nemenidas and Cleopatra

Text is divided into two bands. The top band is separated into three columns, with a thin, serifed vertical line on a slight tilt between each column of text. Each column contains three lines of Greek. The bottom band contains three lines of continuous text, although with a vacat in the first line. Large empty vacat at the bottom of the stone.

Use of alphas with broken mid-bar in top band, but not in bottom. Use of epsilon with arrow crossbar in top band, but not bottom (except for one instance in line 4). Use of lunate epsilon in bottom band, but not in top. Use of lunate sigma in bottom text. Serifs more pronounced in top band. In the top text, Omegas are smaller consistently than the rest of the text. Text in bottom band is carved lightly and irregularly. As Brugnone notes, it seems likely that the lower section was cut by a different hand.
funerary inscription for a family, including nemenidas and cleopatra

Three lines of Greek text. Text is left justified.

Letters are fairly regularly spaced in lines 1-2, but become more irregular in line 3. Letters have light serifs. Letter forms irregular and inconsistent. Two forms of alpha are used: in line one, alpha has an oblique mid-bar which slopes to the right, in lines 2-3, alpha has a broken mid-bar. Omega in line 1 is flat and broad. Beta in line 3 is extremely flat and pointed, and is potentially a correction from a Rho.

Halaesa honours Diogenes Lapiron, son of Diogenes
Five lines of Greek text are preserved, with some of the initial letters lost at the left margin.
The letters are plainly and evenly cut, and well spaced, without serifs. Epsilon has a short middle bar, omicron is full size, omega is open.
The text cannot be precisely dated, but the style of the lettering suggests that it belongs to the 2nd century BCE, rather than the 1st.
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas

Prag and Tigano, 2017, Alesa Archonidea: il lapidarium

A koinon of priests honours [-?-] Lapiron, son of Diogenes

Three lines of Greek text are preserved: the state of the stone means that the beginning and end of all three lines is lost, and at least one further line could have been lost below. If there were any lines above these, they would have been on a separate block of stone.

The letters are regularly cut, with deep terminations to the strokes rather than extended serifs. Epsilon has a shorter middle bar, detached from the main vertical; omicron is very slightly smaller than the other letters; omega is almost, or completely closed, with a slightly elliptical rather than purely circular form.

Apollonia(?) honours Andron son of Thrasios
Four lines of Greek text, not quite centred, but lines 2 and 3 fill the width of the face.

Plain cut letters without serifs, of Hellenistic form. Alpha is straight bar (except possibly  broken bar in line 1); beta has two small closed eyes, with a gap between; epsilon has shorter middle bar; the form of theta is unclear (small circle or cross at centre?); kappa has small arms opening from the mid-point of the vertical; mu has curving middle strokes which reach down to the line, but vertical first and last; omicron is generally slightly smaller than the other letters; pi has equal length strokes without overlap; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omega is closed and very slightly elongated, slightly smaller than other letters.
Photo J.Prag courtesy Soprintendenza BBCCAA di Messina
Bonanno, 2008, Apollonia. Indagini archeologiche sul Monte di San Fratello - Messina, 2003-2005

Three lines of ancient Greek. The first line is partially lost across the top, the second and third are damaged at the left and right margins.

The letters are wide, well spaced and regular in form, and deeply incised. Alpha with straight bar; epsilon has short middle bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes almost full height; omicron is full size; rho has large rounded head, closed; sigma has parallel top and bottom, and middle strokes almost full width; omega is closed, and slightly tear-drop shaped, with horizontal tails.
Photo J. Prag, 2022-05-23, courtesy  Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas
haluntium honours the son of timandros

1(vac.4)ὁ δᾶμος (vac.3)
2Β̣ίωτον Τιμάνδρο[υ]
3εὐνοίας ἕνεκεν̣
The municipium of the Haluntini honours Gnaeus Pollienus
The text occupies five lines over the upper part of the front face.

Regular letters with a fairly square module, simply engraved without serifs. Alpha has broken bar; Kappa has full length arms; Mu has vertical first and last, with mid-strokes only descending half-way; omicron is full size; Pi has full length verticals, and slightly overlapping horizontal bar; omega is slightly open and nearly circular, with horizontal tails/feet.

The use of the term 'municipium' in Greek places this text almost certainly after the grant of Latin rights to Sicily by Julius Caesar (probably 46 BCE), but equally the use of Greek implies a date not later than the early Augustan period. The lettering is compatible with a late Hellenistic date.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2017-07-21

Remains of a centred text on the upper part of the face, with central heading and one line below, with vacat beneath.

Plain letters of regular and equal size, with minimal traces of serifs (but the surface is worn). Alpha with straight bar, epsilon with nearly full length mid-bar; theta with detached mid-stroke; kappa with full length arms; omicron full-size; four-bar sigma with horizontal top and bottom strokes.

Two lines of Greek letters filling the width of the surviving stone

Crude and irregular letters of unequal size, deeply incised. Omicron is small and mid-line; kappa has short equal length arms attached to the vertical; epsilon has shorter middle bar (i the first instance detached from the vertical); alpha has straight bar; rho has rounded closed eye.
Sofia, 2015, Abakainon. Nella dimora di Ade. La necropoli in contrada Cardusa a Tripi

1Δίοκλε
2χαῖρε
Five lines of Greek letters, centred on the stone

Slightly crudely incised simple broad letters without serifs. Nu i sregular; epsilon has slightly shorter middle bar; mu has slightly inward leaning first and last strokes, the mid-strokes reach down to the base-line; rho has a small eye, not always fully closed; alpha has broken bar; omega varies between open circle closed by horizontal bar and closed ovoid form with horizontal bar; phi has a small circular eye; sigma has standard form with horizontal top and bottom storkes; omicron is approximately the same size as other letters.
Manni Piraino, 1976, Contribution Épigraphique à l'Étude de l'esclavage en Sicile

Two lines of Greek letters, centred on the front face of the stone.

Neat, but irregularly sized letters. Omicron is smaller than the rest and mid-line; sigma is regular with horizontal top and bottom bars; kappa is tall with short arms, slightly curving out form the middle of the upright; alpha has straight bar (and in the second case is larger; epsilon has shorter middle bar.
Scan from IGMusPal, courtesy Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas

Single line of Greek letters across the middle of the stone

Regular plain letters. Phi is slightly taller than the rest, but with a small circular eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom bars, with the diagonals joined by a curve; omicron is smaller than the other letters and mid-line.

The text is inscribed on three faces, the precise organisation of which remains a question of discussion. Battistoni 2020 and 2011, after Bormann, offers the most plausible and complete reconstruction, followed here: Section A in two columns on face I (left face for the viewer), continuing upper left on face III (central face for the viewer); Section B in a single column on face II (right face for the viewer); Section C, top of face III, followed by a large lacuna; Section D, lower left of face III; Section E.i, traces top right of face III, followed by a large lacuna; section E.ii, lower right of face III.

Dedication of an altar for Hestia
six lines of Greek letters in a recessed field 23 cm high, with consistent left margin, uneven right margin, at times rather compressed on the right (e.g. line 5), and vacat below.

Neat and regular letters without serfis (but slight terminal marks to the strokes). Alpha with straight cross bar, beta with equal closed eyes, epsilon with short middle stroke, theta slightly ovoid with detached middle bar, kappa with short arms, mu with almost vertical first and last, and three-quarter mid-strokes; xsi with three horizontal bars, lowest the longest; omicron smaller and mid-line, pi with equal vertical strokes; rho rounded closed eye; sigma with very slightly open top and bottom strokes; phi with round eye, slightly extended vertical; omega mostly circular, slightly open, short horizontal feet.
3rd or 2nd century BCE, lettering of the early-mid Hellenistic.

Statue base in honour of Olympis Mestos

The inscription is set out over four lines on the front face of the block on its upper half. The text is roughly centred, lines 1-3 filling the face, line 4 a single word approximately centered. Spacing between words is apparent and increases significantly in line 3.

The letters are regular and with terminal points rather than serfis, and are inscribed in parts in what is almost a punch style, rather than a chiselled groove. Alpha has broken bar; epsilon has mostly equal legnth cross-bars; theta has a full-width cross bar; kappa has full length bars; mu has vertical first and last, three-quarter length mid-strokes; omicron is full-size; pi has eual length verticals; rho has fair-sized closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; omega is rhomboid and closed.
Later Hellenistic, later second or first century BCE?

Inscribed statue base for Gaius Claudius Marcellus

The text is laid out over two lines, off-centre, with the first line set 2-3 letters in from the left margin, the second, longer line c.4 letters in from the left margin. A large single letter appears to sit centrally to the face of the block immediately below lines 1-2.

Simply carved letters, without serifs, showing very slight curvature on the longer strokes (e.g. on alpha). The channels are not always smoothly cut, but rather staccato. Alpha with straight bar; epsilon with shorter middle bar; kappa with medium length arms (not full length); mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes to half height; omicron full size; sigma with horizontal top and bottom strokes.

Edict of Flavius Felix Eumathus regarding the Thermae Achillianae

Greek text over four lines. The fourth line is shorter than the
                                        other three and ends with a vacat. The letters are broadly regular and neatly
                                        cut, but the sizing and spacing varies considerably across the four lines.

Letters are wide and omicron, phi, sigma, epsilon and theta are, on
                                    occasion formed by overlarge circles. Epsilon, sigma and omega are lunate. Xsi is
                                    formed in a distinctive, ornate fashion. Interpuncts are used occasionally, and
                                    formed of an 's' shape, sometimes forward, sometimes backward facing. Numerals are
                                    marked with a supraline.
434 CE (reporting an edict from the consuls of 433)

Alpha has broken bar; epsilon has a squared form, with all bars of equal length, although the middle bar does not always join the vertical; theta a large circle, the middle bar does not extend to the edges; the width of N is variable (at l. 1); mu has four full length strokes, the first and last vertical; rho has a small curved head; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; omega has a straight horizontal bar and a teardrop-shaped body. The carver consistently left a space between words.

Six lines, of which lines 2-6 are indented by one letter compared to line 1, with a consistent left margin. The final line is shorter with the numeral larger and roughly centred. The text is set out over nine lines, complete apart from the very
                                        ends of lines 9 and 10. Chi-rho symbols are set to the left of line two and the
                                        right of line three, and a star is set in the middle between lines one and two.
                                        There is some crowding in the final two lines. The text is approximately centred
                                        on the disc and the crowding at the end of line 8 in particular suggests that
                                        the stone was cut to this circular shape prior to engraving.

The letters are neatly but irregularly cut. Lunate epsilon, sigma and
                                    omega; alpha has a steeply left sloping cross-bar, the right hasta extended well
                                    above the rest of the letter; beta is tall, with two closed eyes, separated from
                                    each other. Supralinear lines are used above numerals and also in line 6.

1Νίκαιος
Greek inscription recording enjoyment of a spring

The text maintains a clear left margin, laid out over three lines. The extended spacing in lines 1 and 2 has sometimes suggested to editors that the text divides into columns; however this is probably to compensate for the fact that lines 2 and 3 are shortened by the insertion of a large engraved palm leaf (20 cm high) on the right margin.

The text is engraved in large bold letters, with the topmost stroke often extended vertically above the letter on Α, Λ, Δ. Letter forms are somewhat variable within the inscription, with lunate and straight sigma used indiscriminately; epsilon is normally straight, but appears lunate in ΦΗϹΕΙΝΟϹ in line 2; alpha is normally straight but displays broken bar in ΕΥΦΡΑΝΘΗΣΑΝ in line 3; phi has an angular eye in lines 1 and 2 but a rounded eye in line 3; variation within texts is however common, and it is not necessary to assume that this reflects different hands in use within the text. Ligatures are employed several times in the text, which has been the source of several confused readings in the past.
3rd century CE or early 4th century CE (Manganaro)

Five lines of Greek text, with a regular left margin, but uneven right margin; line 3 in particular shows signs of cramping in the second half. The lower half of the final line is lost through damage.

Neat, regular letters, mostly of wide module, without serifs. Alpha is broad with straight bar; epsilon has notably short middle bar; kappa has arms of almost full length; omicron is only lightly smaller than other letters (19-20 mm); pi has even length vertical hastae; rho has small closed round head; sigma is four bar with extended horizontal top and bottom strokes; upsilon is neatly symmetrical; phi has small circular eye with vertical only slightly extended (26 mm); omega is full-size and nearly circular, closed, with long horizontal.
later Hellenistic (i.e. 2nd or early 1st century BCE)

Three lines of large letters across the upper part of one of the wider faces. The inscribed field is approximately 0.36 m high x 0.30 m wide. The first line of text is less clear, especially around the upper margin and at the right edge. A continuous horizontal line separates lines 1 and 2.

The letters are engraved in broad, rounded strokes (partly the result of weathering) and have a regular form. K has arms that do not quite reach to the top and bottom of the letter; E has strokes of equal length; A has broken bar. The text is either Latin or a mixture or Latin and Greek, given the presence of L in the second line.

Remains of four lines of Greek text, of which the preserved traces suggest that lines 1-3 filled the width of the stone, but line 4 is more widely spaced and has a vacat at the right, and below.

Regular widely spaced, finely incised letters, of consistent height throughout. Letters have basic triangular terminations to the strokes. Alpha is broken-bar; epsilon has short middle stroke (whether detached or not is unclear); kappa has equal length short arms; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, with the middle strokes extending half-width.
The letter forms would suggest later third or more likely second century BCE
Vidman, 1969, Sylloge inscriptionum religionis Isiacae et Sarapiacae

Four lines of Greek letters; the text appears to be centred on the stone, with slight vacat below.

. Based upon the single published photograph: regularly and neatly carved fine lettters without serfis or significant terminations. Alpha has straight bar; Mu has vertical first and last, with midstrokes descending halfway; omicron is small and mid-line; sigma has diverging top and bottom strokes, the mid-strokes meeting at half width; omega is nearly full height, slightly ovoid, open with short horizontal tails. No editor records the size of the letters.
4th century or 3rd century BCE based on the letters.
Cavallari, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità

Five lines of Greek letters, centred on the wide face of the chest and laid out between guide lines.

Deeply cut lunate letters of somewhat varying height. Kappa has tall vertical, lower tail extends to the line; Pi has vertical strokes of equal length, some overlap by horizontal; Mu has extended serifs off the upper strokes; epsilon and sigma are lunate, the cross-bar of the epsilon sometimes very lightly cut and detached; alpha and delta have extended serifs on the upper strokes; there is a single comma-shaped interpunct in line 1 after the first letter.

(Following Orsi's apograph in his taccuino) Small regular neat letters with terminations to the strokes but no signficant serifs. Alpha has straight bar; Epislon has slightly shortened middle bar; Zeta is vertical with wide top and bottom horizontal strokes; Kappa has slightly shortened arms; Mu has vertical first and last, with the middle strokes almost reaching to the base line; omicron is full-size; Sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; Omega is round full-sized, and almost closed.
2nd or 1st century BCE by the lettering which is later Hellenistic
